EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

Stationary Source & Regulated Substance (RS)

The Blythe Energy Project is owned by FPL Energy Operating Services, Inc, and located near the City of Blythe, Riverside County, California. The project site is located just west of the City of Blythe and directly adjacent to and east of the Blythe Airport. 

The Blythe Energy Project generates electricity from two high-efficiency, natural gas-fired turbines and one heat recovery steam generator.  The facility SIC code is 4911, and the NAICS code is 221119.  FPL Energy Operating Services is committed to safe, environmentally sensitive operation of the Blythe facility.  The Blythe Energy Project is operated in compliance with all federal, state, and local environmental and safety regulations.  Emergency response coordination procedures are in place with local emergency response agencies.  

Aqueous and anhydrous ammonia are the substances of interest for this document.  The covered processes include both the storage and use of aqueous and anhydrous ammonia.  Aqueous ammonia is used to reduce NOx (oxides of nitrogen) in the exhaust gas emissions through a Selective Catalytic Reduction (SCR) module or DeNOx system.  The Blythe Energy Project is physically located in a sparsely populated, largely agricultural area west of the City of Blythe. The nearest areas normally used by the public include the airport to the west and a municipal golf course to the northeast. 

The refrigeration system uses 54,975 pounds of ammonia to chill the air intake of a combustion turbine electrical generator.  The system cycles ammonia through various physical states - high pressure liquid, low pressure liquid, low pressure vapor, high pressure vapor, then back to high pressure liquid.  Typical operating conditions consist of approximately 65 psig on the low pressure side of the system and 200 psig on the high side.

The process begins with high pressure liquid ammonia draining from the Condensers to the SOC Receiver.  The SOC

Receiver maintains a liquid reservoir for oil cooling of the Screw Compressors (5) via a modulating control valve on the outlet to the Flash Receiver.  The control valve is connected to the liquid level in the vessel, and allows excess liquid to flow to the Flash Receiver, at which point the pressure of the liquid ammonia is partially decreased.  The ammonia vapor produced by this partial drop in pressure is drawn from the receiver through the economizer suction port of the Compressors.  Liquid ammonia is fed from the Flash Receiver to the Pump Receiver package.

The Pump Receiver uses five pumps to transfer the liquid ammonia to the Combustion Turbine Inlet Chilling System.  Two pumps feed each of the two Chillers, while the fifth pump is reserved for back-up purposes.  At the Chillers, liquid ammonia partially boils as it absorbs heat from the air intake of the combustion turbine.  The resultant liquid/vapor mix returns to the Pump Receiver where liquid drops to the bottom of the vessel and the Compressors pull suction from the top.

The energy input to the system is supplied by five Compressors.  Each Compressor draws main suction from the Pump Receiver and economizer suction from the Flash Receiver.  As the name suggests, the purpose for using economizer suction is to increase the efficiency of the Compressors, thereby reducing their cost of operation.  Liquid injection oil cooling is provided by the SOC Receiver, and all Compressors discharge high pressure vapor to the Condensers which are located outside the Equipment Room.  The Condensers convert the high pressure discharge to liquid by spraying water and fan-blowing air over coils filled with the ammonia vapor.  The resulting high pressure ammonia liquid drains to the SOC Receiver to begin the cycle again.


Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

A key part of the RMP program is the process hazard analysis (PHA).  A PHA was performed for an aqueous ammonia storage and use process at a

nother facility owned and operated by the parent company of Blythe Energy, LLC (FPL Energy).  That PHA, which is adopted for use at the Blythe facility, was performed using the Hazards and Operability Study (HazOp) procedure per OSHA guidelines and the guidelines published by the American Institute of Chemical Engineers.  The HazOp for aqueous ammonia concluded that potential deviations were of the ¿acceptable with appropriate controls¿ category or ¿acceptable as is¿ and identified appropriate response procedures to be used in the remote likelihood of their occurrence.  A supplemental ¿What If¿ analysis was also performed. 

The Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) for the anydrous ammonia system, which was completed on March 11th and 12th, 2003,  included a Hazard and Operability (HAZOP) study as well as a Facility What If Walkthrough.  The PHA provided mitigation measures to improve safety at the Blythe Energy Project.

As a part of the preparation of the RMP program, Blythe Energy, LLC reviewed a hazards and operability study (HAZOP) of an aqueous ammonia storage and distribution system for another plant owned by their parent company.  The Blythe Energy Project¿s SCR DeNOx (aqueous ammonia) system is very similar to the model that was reviewed. 

The objective of the HAZOP study is to identify potential hazards and their causes, consequences and appropriate mitigation responses or actions to counter the identified hazards. The HAZOP procedures performed at the other facility were adopted for use at the Blythe Energy Project.  On September 23, 2002, The Blythe Energy Production Team convened to perform a HAZOP study for the Blythe Power Project. This HAZOP study will be reviewed during the annual compliance audit. 

Blythe Energy Project has complied with the RMP requirements and is committed to review and enhance the program periodically as appropriate and in compliance with the program requirements. The RMP program documents are complete and accessible to all interes

ted persons at all times.  We believe our program is proactive and not only meets regulatory requirements but also confirms our commitment to workplace safety as our number one priority. 


Hazard Assessment Summary

The worst-case release scenario(s) and the alternative release scenario(s) for Aqueous Ammonia

The HazOp study reported in section 2.1 of this document shows that the only potentially significant RS release would be from the ammonia storage and distribution system. The Most Likely Release was identified as a rupture of the distribution piping immediately downstream of the ammonia vaporizer (SCR skid). The release rate would be limited to the capacity of the vaporizer, 1,000 lb/hr. The rupture would cause audible alarms to sound in the facility's control room for ammonia flow and distribution pressure, and NOx emissions.  As a result, it is highly probable that the operators will shut down the ammonia release within 20 minutes.

There are no sensitive receptors within the immediate area surrounding the Blythe Energy Project. In particular, the nearest school is 4.5 miles east of the Blythe Energy facility.

Dispersion modeling was performed using the Area Location of Hazardous Atmospheres model (ALOHA, version 5.2); a program, developed by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (U.S. EPA) and the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA).  This model accepts surface meteorological data, including wind speed, direction, and temperature, and upper atmosphere inversion height, for one hour. It determines whether a gas cloud with a density substantially greater than air will be formed, and uses either a Gaussian or dense gas algorithm, as appropriate, to determine AHM concentrations in the vicinity of the release point.  Unfortunately, the ALOHA program cannot directly model solutions which contain mixture such as aqueous ammonia (ammonia and water) because the ALOHA program assumes that the entire content of an aqueous ammonia release is anh

ydrous ammonia and the release behaves with the same physical properties as anhydrous ammonia.  Therefore, using conventional ALOHA program inputs would significantly over predict the threat zone of an aqueous ammonia spill.

NOAA Report No. HAZMAT 93-3, entitled ¿Modeling Hydrochloric Acid Evaporation in ALOHA¿, published by the Modeling and Simulation Studies Branch, Hazardous Material Response and Assessment Division, Office of Ocean Research Conservation and Assessment, developed a method for modeling mixed solutions such as aqueous ammonia.  The modeling method used in this report is based on determining evaporation rates of low flashpoint materials in solution from a liquid pool.  The evaporation formula in the report is based on pool area, low flashpoint material mass transfer rates, and molecular weight of the material flashing, vapor pressure of the material, gas constant, and ambient temperature.  Once the evaporation rate is established, conventional inputs to the ALOHA program can be used to determine the maximum threat zones.

The evaporation rate of aqueous ammonia from a tank release in the secondary containment area proposed for the Blythe Energy Project was calculated to be 0.127 kg/s (kilogram per second), at an ambient temperature of 100°F and wind speed of 1 m/s (meter per second).  This was assumed to be the worst-case release scenario.  Worst-case meteorological conditions for the modeling were assumed to be F stability class, wind speed of 1 m/s, and ambient temperatures of 100°F.  

The scenario was also run for stability class D at a wind speed of 5.0 m/s and ambient temperature of 100°F.  This weather condition represents the likely actual meteorological condition at the Blythe Energy power plant site.  The hand calculated evaporation rate for this condition was determined to be 0.445 kg/s.  

When comparing stability class F to stability class D modeling results, a significant reduction occurs in the maximum threat zone.  Therefore, the st

ability class F can be considered the absolute worst-case modeling scenario for a release from the aqueous ammonia storage tanks at the Blythe Energy power plant.


The worst-case release scenario(s) and the alternative release scenario(s) for Anydrous Ammonia

An off-site consequence analysis was also performed for the anyhrdous ammonia system, the results of which are described below.

Worst Case Release Result Summary
The worst case release scenario is a release of the total quantity of ammonia in the largest vessel in the ammonia refrigeration system, taking into account administrative controls that limit the maximum quantity in the vessel.  If a vessel is located inside a building, the EPA allows a passive mitigation factor of 55% to be used in calculating the release rate to the outside atmosphere when the release is enclosed by a building.

The Pump Receiver, located inside the compressor room, can hold the entire ammonia charge.  Therefore the entire charge of ammonia (54,975 lbs) is assumed to be released inside an enclosure.  This results in a release rate of 3,033 lbs to the outside atmosphere.

For analyzing the worst case release scenario, EPA requires the use of the most pessimistic meteorological conditions that will allow for the maximum downwind exposure.  Low wind speeds (1.5 m/s) and stable atmospheric conditions (F stability) will allow the gas cloud to travel as far as possible by limiting cloud dispersion.  The results are conservative.

EPA's 'Risk Management Program Guidance for Ammonia Refrigeration,' May 2000, Exhibit 4-4 was used to find the downwind distance for the worst case release to 200 ppm in an urban setting.  The RMP*Comp Model developed by the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration and EPA was used to prepare the data in this guidance document.  This guidance document provides data for ammonia refrigeration systems and will ensure consistency throughout the industry.

This release reaches off site and may impact populati

on receptors.  No environmental receptors were affected by this potential release.  

Note: Item 2-6 is required to be reported to 1 significant-figure and is the mitigated release rate, where as item 2-5 is the total quantity and is reported to 2 significant figures.

Note: This process resulted in the Worst Case release from the facility.

Alternative Release Result Summary
A release of ammonia resulting from a 0.25 inch diameter hole in a pipe for one hour.  The release rate of ammonia due to the pressure of the tank is 144 pounds per minute.  The meteorological conditions used were 3 meters per second wind speed and D stability.  Reference tables in the Risk Management Program Guidance for Ammonia Refrigeration were used to determine the maximum distance to the toxic endpoint of 200 ppm in urban conditions.  This release reaches off site.  No population or environmental receptors were affected by this potential release.

Note: Item 3-5 is required to be reported to 2 significant figures and item 3-6 is required to be reported to 1 significant figure.


The general accidental release prevention program and chemical-specific prevention steps

The Blythe Energy Project and its management subscribe to the safe practices outlined in the OSHA 29 CFR 1910.119 program, namely, those programs which ensure:
¿ Employees are adequately trained,
¿ Equipment mechanical integrity,
¿ Safe management of change,
¿ Equipment/instrument designs that minimize incident potential,
¿ Incident investigations generate corrective actions to minimize recurrence, and
¿ Operating procedures are relevant and minimize the risk of incidents


The five-year accident history

This is a new facility and as such does not have an accident history.  We are not aware of significant incidents involving similar facilities from which this facility was designed.


The emergency response program

The plant has a current ¿Emergency Action Plan¿ in accordance with 29 CFR 1910.38(a) (Action Plans).  Employees

have been trained in the plan and the plan is reviewed frequently to verify that it is current with plant operating practice.  Additionally, the facility has developed a procedures which include actions necessary for controlling incidental releases of hazardous materials including those designated as highly hazardous chemicals by 29 CFR 1910.119. Additionally, emergency response procedures are included with the required Hazardous Materials Business Plan, submitted to the local Riverside County Environmental Health Department with a copy to all emergency response agencies.  Copies of the appropriate emergency procedures available in the administration building and the manned control rooms.   

Planned changes to improve safety

This is a new facility and it has been designed and built using ¿state-of-the-art¿ engineering and safety technology.  Prior to plant startup, a pre-startup safety review (PSSR) will be conducted and last minute design changes will be made based on the findings of the PSSR.  All changes to the plant are subject to the facility ¿Management of Change¿ (MOC) procedure which ensures a thorough review of all environment, health and safety issues to maintain expected safety performance.

Periodic environment, health, and safety audits are used to gather sufficient facts and information to verify compliance with standards and to determine what changes could be made to improve safety. The plant's General Manager is responsible for ensuring that these periodic audits are performed.  The audits includes an evaluation of the design and effectiveness of the process safety management system and a field inspection of the safety and health conditions and practices to verify that the systems are being effectively implemented. Audits are conducted or led by a person knowledgeable in audit techniques. The essential elements of the audit program include planning, staffing, conducting the audit, evaluating hazards and deficiencies and taking corrective action, p

erforming follow up and documenting actions.

Audits are performed to verify that the procedures and practices developed in this RMP Manual are adequate and are being followed.  The purpose of these audits is to educate employees on the appropriate method to apply the RMP plan, and not to take disciplinary actions.  The process and its operations being audited relate only to the aqueous and anhydrous ammonia systems.  Audits includesa review of the RMP Manual, inspection of the physical facilities, and interviews with all levels of plant personnel.  A checklist that details the requirements of each section of the standard is used during the audit. 

Through interviews, the auditor evaluates employees' knowledge and awareness of the safety procedures, duties, rules, and emergency response assignments. During the inspection, the auditor notes actual practices such as safety and health policies, procedures, and work authorization procedures. This approach enables the auditor to identify deficiencies and determine where corrective actions or improvements are necessary.  

Periodic audits, operating procedures are reviewed periodically using a ¿job safety analysis¿ (JSA) process.  The JSA examines procedures through actual observation while the procedures are being performed.  Procedures are modified as necessary to improve environment, health and safety performance.  JSAs along with daily inspections by supervision are used to specify training needs and these needs are used to develop training programs.

In addition, any incidents that may occur are fully investigated to determine the root cause(s) and for developing corrective actions to minimize recurrence.


Turbine Inlet Chilling System Process Hazard Analysis Recommendations:

R01: Consider establishing a policy that all ammonia operators wear goggles or face shields when working on the ammonia system.

R02: Establish an awareness training program that includes providing the following information to all employees o

f the facility: 1) the presence of and the hazards associated with ammonia at the facility, 2) how to recognize the odor of ammonia, 3) what to do if they observe an ammonia leak, and 4) where to go when they are told to evacuate.

R03: Consider using the same evacuation plans for all emergencies, i.e. fire, ammonia, etc.

R04: If the facility decides to purchase respirators, a maintenance program must be implemented.

R05: Establish a maintenance program for the ammonia leak sensors, which includes periodic tests and calibrations, as well as periodic tests of the chemical cell.  Include in Mechanical Integrity.

R06: Establish a policy that unnecessary flammables are not to be stored in the Engine Room under any circumstances.

R07: Prepare an operating procedure to address manually purging from the Condensers.

R08: Establish a policy to replace or recertify relief valves when they unseat or every 5 years, per the industry standard.  Include in Mechanical Integrity.

R09: Consider including in the mechanical integrity program that a comparison of the computer readouts and actual system parameters (levels, temperatures, pressures, etc.) should be conducted on an annual basis.

R10: Include in the mechanical integrity program a daily walk through of the Engine Room.  Record some typical system parameters (temperatures, pressures, levels, etc.)

R11: Include an annual test of the high level float switch operation on the Flash Receiver and Pump Recirculator in the Mechanical Integrity program.

R12: Establish a policy that only trained operators are to manually drain oil.

R13: Consider keeping the Engine Room locked at all times and restrict access to authorized personnel.

R14: Establish a training program to train operators that water should not be sprayed on a liquid ammonia spill.

R15: Establish a training program train operators to investigate all equipment shutdowns when the cause of the shutdown is unknown.

R16: Establish a policy that when a pump is taken o

ut of service for a prolonged period, the associated check valve is protected by closing the downstream valve.

R17: Consider maintaining a file for each piece of equipment that contains a record of all related maintenance operations that have been performed.

R18: Establish a training program to train operators to exercise caution when approaching the chiller system during shutdown situations.  A leak may not be evident during normal operations.

R19: Ensure that the Condensers are maintained including a regular water treatment program and a periodic cleaning of the water reservoir.  Include in Mechanical Integrity.

R20: Institute facility lockout/tagout program when working on the condensers.

R21: Establish a training program to train operators that they should not remove ¿nodules' when cleaning Condenser piping.  Nodules are indicative of a pinhole leak and removing them could result in an ammonia release.

R22: Maintain compressors per manufacturer's recommendations.

R23: Establish a training program to train operators that they should not trap liquid when isolating portions of piping.

R24: Establish a policy that all ammonia odors are investigated.  Detecting and rectifying a problem early will prevent more serious situations from developing.

R25: Establish a policy that when a Compressor is taken out of service, the associated check valve is protected by closing the downstream valve.

R26: Include a check of compressor oil levels in the daily walkthrough.  Add as necessary.  See R09.

R27: Include Refrigerant Diffusion Tank in maintenance program.

Human Factors Checklist
R28: Establish a training program to instruct operators to wear ear-protection when working in the Engine Room.

R29: Ensure that valve tags are added when the system is completed.

Facility Siting Checklist
R30: Install windsocks in locations that are visible from primary access points.

R31: Ensure that evacuation locations are not situated above manhole covers.

Emergency Response Act

ion Plan Checklist
R32: Establish, and document, who is to accept the role of information officer.  The information officer will be responsible for notifying the appropriate agencies in the event of an emergency.

R33: Establish, and document, who has authority to activate the emergency stop button.

EPA Alert Checklist
R34: Consider adding ¿Caution - Ammonia' signage to the Engine Room doors.

R35: Install eyewash and safety showers outside Engine Room exit.

R36: Consider insulating the outdoor water used in the eyewash/safety showers.

R37: Include in Mechanical Integrity that the valves on the Compressor Suction lines should be exercised annually.

R38: Include a periodic visual inspection of the Condenser spray nozzles in Mechanical Integrity.



Blythe Energy, LLC prepared this RMP program document in conjunction with our consultants and vendors.
